dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Facebook, you know, just dropped their latest transparency report, and get this, it actually includes data from Twitter for the first time, which is kind of a big deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Facebook, you know, just dropped their latest transparency report, and get this, it actually includes data from Twitter for the first time, which is kind of a big deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company revealed its sweeping efforts to police its own network in its latest biannual transparency report, which includes data from Instagram for the first time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're really pushing this narrative that, um, most of the content, like, the bad stuff, is identified automatically. Before users even see it, thanks to AI.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're really pushing this narrative that, um, most of the content, like, the bad stuff, is identified automatically. Before users even see it, thanks to A I.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook says it identifies most of the content automatically using artificial intelligence and advanced software before users can ever see it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but then you dig a little deeper, and the most shocking part, I think, is this dramatic decrease in, uh, child pornography removal. It's... it's pretty wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, they say they removed about 5.6 million pieces of child nudity and exploitation in Q3, which sounds like a lot, but that's roughly *half* of what they removed in Q1. Like, a 50% drop.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook says that it removed about 11.6 million pieces of content it deemed to be child nudity and sexual exploitation of children in the third quarter, roughly double the number of pieces of content removed for the same reason in the first quarter.

dialogue_turns.text: And on Instagram, it's 2.4 million photos and videos over Q2 and Q3. So, still big numbers, but the trend is... concerning, you know?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Instagram, it removed 1.2 million photos and videos involving child nudity or exploitation over the second and third quarters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Zuckerberg, he's, like, trying to spin it, right? He's saying, "Just because we're reporting big numbers doesn't mean there's more harmful content." He says it means "we're working harder."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Zuckerberg, he's, like, trying to spin it, right? He's saying, Just because we're reporting big numbers doesn't mean there's more harmful content. He says it means we're working harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just because were reporting big numbers doesnt mean theres so much more harmful content happening on our services than others. ... What it says is were working harder to identify this and take action on it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But not everyone's buying that. Congress, for one, is giving him a lot of heat. Representative Ann Wagner, I mean, she really laid into him at a recent hearing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But not everyone's buying that. Congress, for one, is giving him a lot of heat. Representative Ann Wagner, I mean, she really laid into him at a recent hearing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Representative Ann Wagner (R-MO) scolded Zuckerberg at the hearing, saying, You are not working hard enough, and end-to-end encryption is not going to help the problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, how does he, um, defend the end-to-end encryption then, if it makes it harder to *see* content? That seems like a direct contradiction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, he admits there's a "tension." But he claims that even with encryption, they can still detect violations through "behavior patterns." Like, who's messaging whom, that kind of thing.

He said content violations can often be detected through behavior patterns, such as who is messaging whom.
